prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We expect line widths between 1 and 2 km/s. We aim to have at least 5 channels to correctly resolve the lines (0.17 km/s spectral resolution). Because N2D+ has hyperfine structures, we choose in the OT a narrower line width to have the option of using 0.08 km/s if needed. However, 0.17 km/s is sufficient for our science.
We also have a baseband for continuum with channels of 1.2 km/s. The primary use of it is for continuum, but the possible detection high velocity gas in CO is important. Th non-detection of CO will further confirm the prestellar nature of the clumps and cores.

We require an angular resolution of 1.5", which corresponds to 7500 AU at the distance of 5 kpc. This is the typical size for low mass cores found by Kirk et al. (2006) in Perseus (~5000-10000 AU corresponds to 1-2" at 5 kpc).
The angular size of 38" is slightly larger than the physical size of the clumps at 3 kpc (FWHM size~0.5 pc). Because for this proposal is crucial to extend the search of cores in the whole clump and just outside them, an angular size larger than the typical size of the clumps was chosen.
ALMA observations of IRDCs have not taken in consideration the extended flux filtered out by the 12-m array. Although we are looking for high-mass cores that are mostly formed by compact, dense gas (~10^6 1/cm^3), it is important to evaluate the contribution of the more extended, lower density gas. As also mentioned in the science goal, the lower density gas that can be filtered out by the 12-m array, is significant to determine the mass of the low-mass cores. ACA is fundamental in this proposal.
The few ALMA studies done so far on IRDCs just focus on single pointing observations at 230 and 345 GHz. The field of view is small at this frequencies and only the densest parts of the clumps can be observed. Foster et al. (2014) have shown on one IRDC that star formation occurs not only at the center of the clumps. Therefore, because we will search for low-mass cores, we require to cover the whole extend of the clump. This is way mosacing is extremely important in this proposal.

We will observe at 230 GHz because (1) is a good compromise between the area covered by the primary beam (27") and good sensitivity for continuum from cold gas, and (2) because several tracers of cold gas can be simultaneously observed (N2D+, DCO+, DCN).
The observing time is largely constrained by the line sensitivity. We will mosaic each clump to obtain a line sensitivity of 20 mJy per channel of 0.17 km/s. According to the observations of the same set of lines by Tan et al. (2013), we would obtain a S/N of 5 for N2D+ in the weakest of their sources. In the case of unexpected low intensity for the lines or for the cores of lower mass and density, we can smooth the data to 2"-2.5" to increase the S/N ratio. We note that Tan et al. (2013) detected N2D+ and DCO+ in all their dust cores with masses larger than 0.8 Msun.
The continuum sensitivity on 4.1 GHz bandwidth is 0.1 mJy. At the distance of 5 kpc, a 4sigma detection corresponds to 0.4 Msun at 12 K. This is enough to search for the low-mass cores we mentioned in the science goal. Cores with larger masses will be easily detected.
We are not limited in sensitivity to search for high-mass prestellar cores. All above estimation are for sources around 5 kpc. Only 2 of the target sources are at 5 kpc. The other 10 are at ~3 kpc, thus all the sensitivities estimated above are lower limits. We will definitively detect strong emission in line and continuum emission.

Due to the nature of the sources selected in this proposal, line widths are extremely narrow compared with other molecular clouds with active high-mass star formation. We require a good spectral resolution in all the deuterated molecules mentioned in the proposal (N2D+, DCO+, DCN, CCD).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The lack of a significant amount of prestellar, high-mass cluster-forming clumps has made hard to conclusively refute or support models of high-mass star formation. In addition, the insufficient sensitivity and angular resolution have done challenging to unambiguously test observational predictions. For this proposal, we have carefully selected a sample of massive clumps in the earliest stages of evolution (dark at 70 um). With ALMA, we will mosaic these clumps and recover the missing flux with ACA to: look for high-mass cores, determine their virial parameters and search for low-mass cores. Because the large sample of clumps in this proposal, we expect to detect more than a 100 cores. Thus, we will draw difinitive conclusions on which model of high-mass star formation better represent the observations in a statistical way.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: ALMA Project Office, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
